rows.title: Café Cleopatra
rows.description: At 1230 Saint-Laurent Boulevard, a boulevard that used to be called The Main, we find one of the rare vestiges of the Red Light district that still resists change: the Café Cléopâtre. Housed in a building built in 1895, which has always been occupied by cabarets or nude dancers' bars since its erection, the Café Cléopâtre has been part of the Montreal landscape since 1970.  Located in the heart of the old Red Light, this emblematic cabaret proudly embraces the historical heritage of this neighbourhood by offering burlesque evenings whose eroticism and tone are reminiscent of the hot Montreal nights of the 1920s.  However, despite its popularity among both the heterosexual and LGBTQ+ communities, this Montreal institution has had to resist several attempts to expropriate it throughout its history.  In fact, as early as 2009, when the Quartier des Spectacles was created, the Angus Development Corporation, which was partly responsible for the redevelopment of the neighbourhood, made several offers to the owner of Café Cléopâtre to take possession of its premises.  However, after a highly publicized saga that lasted more than two years, the Café Cléopâtre finally won out over the real estate developers who wanted to replace this century-old building with a twelve-storey building that would have been occupied by offices and businesses.  However, the Café Cléopâtre's victory did not prevent the Quartier des Spectacles project from coming into being. This new central district of Montreal's cultural scene, the heir to the Red Light, has a red circle as its logo, reminiscent of the name that this sector of Montreal once bore.

rows.title: Le Bordel Comédie-Club
rows.description: The name of the popular comedy club that this address houses is anything but insignificant. In fact, the Bordel Comédie-Club takes its name from one of the most famous Montreal brothels of the 1940s and 1950s that was located at the same address.  At the time, the club was more than three floors high and had six different access points. In order to satisfy its clientele at all hours of the day and night, the brothel employed more than 75 women who alternated day and night shifts.  However, not just anyone could enter the brothel: those who wished to visit had to be referred by a taxi driver or another client in order to get an invitation.  Such was the popularity of this brothel that the mere mention of the door number was enough for the taxi drivers who knew perfectly well where the client wanted to go.  Many years after its closure in the 1950s, people looking for entertainment continued to ring the doorbell of this legendary address.  The situation was so problematic that the new owners decided to remove the numbers from their door for several years.  Today, the many comedians who own and frequent the Bordel comédie-club continue to feed the Montreal entertainment scene...in a legal manner, just like the old Bordel.

rows.title: Casa Loma/281
rows.description: The intersection of Berger Street and St. Catherine Street East has long been Montreal's premier nightlife spot. Throughout the 1950s and 1960s, one of the city's most popular cabarets was located on this corner: Casa Loma.  Having made it their mission to discover local talent, the owners of the Casa Loma succeeded: Ginette Reno played there several times at the beginning of her career, while Alys Robi took advantage of the place's popularity to give her own career a second wind.  However, the close ties between this establishment and organized crime led the owners of Casa Loma to close the establishment in 1971 after a triple murder took place inside the cabaret.  In 2004, 94 St. Catherine Street East once again became a hub of Montreal's nightlife when the nude dance club 281 moved into the former Casa Loma premises.  This Montreal institution catered to a predominantly female clientele for over 40 years until it closed its doors for good in 2020.  The building and its activities have been, until recently, worthy heirs to the nightlife of the old Red Light district.

rows.title: Pavillon Purvis (auparavant la maison Sir Mortimer B. Davis
rows.description_en: Le pavillon Purvis fut construit en 1907 pour Sir Mortimer B. Davis, fondateur de la compagnie Imperial Tobacco. Il engagea pour ce faire les architectes John McGregor et Robert Findlay, ce dernier étant celui qui a conçu l'édifice de la Sun Life. Il fut l'un des seuls juifs à appartenir à une communauté composée essentiellement de membres d'origine écossaise dans le quartier connu sous le nom de «Square Mile» ou «mille carré». Cet hôtel particulier au tempérament classique du style français Beaux-Arts, construit en pierre calcaire d'Indiana, est pourvu d'une façade symétrique décorée de pierre sculptée et de fer au travail complexe, cache une charpente moderne en béton et en fer, et possède des planchers de béton armé. Chaque étage fut agencé autour d'un hall central et tout autant ornementé que l'extérieur, dans un style toutefois plus chaleureux. L'architecture intérieure se caractérise entre autres par des rampes d'escalier et des chandeliers sculptés, des meubles faits sur commande, de même qu'une serre vitrée, une particularité très en demande pour les maisons de ce quartier chic.
rows.address: 1020, avenue des Pins Ouest adresse secondaires: 3661-3737, rue Peel Montréal

rows.title: Pavillon Chancelor Day, université Mc Gill (Maison James Ross)
rows.description_en: Les travaux ont été réalisés dans la partie la plus ancienne du bâtiment, où se trouvent les bureaux du département. Notre mission était au départ de restaurer les fenêtres et d’importantes boiseries, mais aussi de mettre à jour le système de chauffage et les systèmes électriques.

rows.title: Maison Hosmer - Université McGill
rows.description_en: Construite en 1900-1901 selon les plans de l’architecte Edward Maxwell, cette résidence est érigée pour Charles R. Hosmer, industriel prolifique qui est notamment président de la Ogilvie Flour Mills et directeur du Canadien Pacifique. Le célèbre architecte paysagiste Frederick G. Todd a conçu l’aménagement du terrain, aujourd’hui disparu.

rows.title: Test geofence
rows.description_en: description test geofence Lorem Ipsum je jednostavno probni tekst koji se koristi u tiskarskoj i slovoslagarskoj industriji. Lorem Ipsum postoji kao industrijski standard još od 16-og stoljeća, kada je nepoznati tiskar uzeo tiskarsku galiju slova i posložio ih da bi napravio knjigu s uzorkom tiska. Taj je tekst ne samo preživio pet stoljeća, već se i vinuo u svijet elektronskog slovoslagarstva, ostajući u suštini nepromijenjen. Postao je popularan tijekom 1960-ih s pojavom Letraset listova s odlomcima Lorem Ipsum-a, a u skorije vrijeme sa software-om za stolno izdavaštvo kao što
